content.title: How do I edit my order?
content.content:
To edit payment methods, shipping information, modify subscription (frequency), or order content, you will need to access your account at www.brunomd.com. At the top right corner of the homepage click the ‘log-in’ link above the shopping cart. Be aware that you will need an account to make changes and will need to create one if you did not do it at the time of purchase. We encourage you to use the same email address that was used when the purchase was made to link the order to your account. If an account has already been created simply log in using your email address and password. You can do this by clicking the ‘log-in’ link above the cart icon on the home page (top right-hand corner) and sign in. You will be redirected to the order history page and on the order line there is an option to ‘cancel/edit’ your order.

If you need further assistance, feel free to contact us via email at customercare@brunopharma.com.

• Please use the same email address that was used when the purchase was made to link the order to the account.

• If an account has already been created simply log in using your email address and password. You can do this by clicking the ‘log-in’ link above the shopping cart, on the home page (top right-hand corner). You will be redirected to the order history page and on the order line there is an option to ‘cancel/edit’ your order.

• If you need further assistance, feel free to contact us via email at customercare@brunopharma.com, or by calling our customer care department at Toll Free # 866-816-3400.

2.If you want to cancel your first order that has been shipped, follow the instructions below:

• You will need to create a returns request via our returns center. You can access this by visiting our site www.brunomd.com and navigating to the returns tab located at the bottom of the homepage.

• Click on “Returns” (Under the Company tab). You will be redirected to the returns center page, and there you will be prompted to input your order number and email address to start the process. As there is no need to return the first order, we will refund you in full once we have received your request. Our system will generate an RMA, please ignore it. You will be refunded in full once your request has been processed by our customer care department.

3.If you want to cancel any subsequent orders including subscribe and save orders, follow the instructions below:

• You will need to access your order at www.brunomd.com (Top right of the homepage) to handle any rescheduling or cancellation related to any subsequent orders or any subscribe & save orders.

• However, if you are unable to make the necessary changes or require further assistance, please do not hesitate to contact us by email at customercare@brunopharma.com or call us at 1-866-816-3400 where a member of our support team will be happy to assist you.

4.If you want to return your orders, follow the instructions below:

• There is no need to return your first order. Although our systems will generate an RMA, please ignore it. We offer a full refund for your first order without the hassle of having to return any product. You will be refunded in full once your request has been processed by our customer care department.

• To receive a full refund, all subsequent orders, or all subscribe & save orders must be returned unopened and sealed. We do not issue refunds or credits on damaged, opened or used merchandise after your first order and on subscribe & save orders.

Your order will not be eligible to return 30 days after the order date. If you are unable to complete this process or require further assistance, do not hesitate to email us at customercare@brunopharma.com, or to call us at 1-866-816-3400.

Instructions on how to return your order:

1. Access the brunomd.com and go to “Returns” (Under Company Tab). Make sure your order is within 30 days from the purchase date.

2. You will be given a Returned Merchandise Authorization Number (RMA). No refunds will be given without an RMA number and the package will be refused. RMA numbers will be valid for 10 days only. A refund will be issued upon approval of eligibility.

Bruno Pharma innovations

8791 Cobblestone Point Circle Boynton Beach, FL 33472

content.title: What are the 5 in 1 benefits of Royal Collagen Peptides?
content.content:
1. Skin Health Improving - elasticity, hydration, fine lines, wrinkles, ligaments, and tendons

2. Bone Health Improving - bone stability, flexibility, and density

3. Nail Health Promoting - growth and health of fingernails

4. Hair Health Promoting - healthier hair growth

5. Joint Health Measurable -recovery of joint cartilage

content.title: What is a Highly Purified Collagen Peptides Complex?
content.content:
Specific Collagen Peptides sourced from Italy, Germany, Great Britain,other EU countries.

Our Specific Collagen Peptides are a breakthrough because they are proven to stimulate the creation of new collagen at any age. The benefits are many: improved skin texture, glow, and elasticity, stronger nails, and more youthful hair with renewed luster and bounce. The advantages are not merely cosmetic. Specific Collagen Peptides increase collagen levels throughout the body to restore cartilage, so you'll move better, and increase bone density to keep your bones strong.

content.title: How are Royal Collagen Peptides different from other collagen products?
content.content: The vast majority of collagen products available on the market today do not address the issue of collagen biosynthesis (the body’s ability to create its own collagen.) They combat the problem of collagen degeneration by offering a supplement that focuses on offsetting the loss. Royal Specific Collagen Peptides both offset the loss and maximize stimulation of the human cell types responsible for collagen biosynthesis, giving the body “fuel” to create collagen and improve skin, hair, nail, joints, and bone health.

content.title: How do Royal Collagen Peptides help reduce the appearance of wrinkles?
content.content:
Royal Collagen Peptides work in two ways: first, they stimulate the activity of the fibroblasts. Fibroblasts are cell types that build fibers and molecular components of the connective tissue, giving the skin its structure and firmness. Activating the fibroblasts encourages the production of new collagen structures as well as the ones from hyaluronic acid. Hyaluronic acid can bind a great deal of water and is indispensable for tight, firmer-looking skin. This process takes some time, but with consistency and determination, your skin regains its natural tone and improves its moisture-storing capacity.

Royal Collagen Peptides provide the skin with its necessary “building blocks.” Their mode of action is exceptionally sophisticated. They perfectly resemble the fragments which form when skin collagen degrades. Our bodies recognize these peptides as degradation products and boost our collagen synthesis. Thanks to the considerably higher production of natural collagen, the skin can repair itself and replace what was lost through age and environmental influencers.

content.title: Why are Royal Collagen Peptides important for connective tissues?
content.content: Connective tissue includes the skin, ligaments, tendons, cartilage, and joint cartilage, as well as the fasciae and blood vessels.Collagen is the main component of connective tissue and structural tissue and is found everywhere in the body. It gives bones, joints, tendons, ligaments, and muscles strength and flexibility. If the collagenous structures are degraded by heavy stress, like working out, or by the normal aging process, the function of all organs and tissues that depend on collagen are impaired. Ligaments and tendons weaken, muscle mass decreases, and the loss of vital cartilage tissue at the joints can lead to painful symptoms. Fibroblasts are cell types responsible for collagen biosynthesis in the connective tissue. They build fibers and molecular components of the connective tissue, giving the skin structure and firmness. Activating the fibroblasts encourages the production of new collagen structures as well as the ones from hyaluronic acid.

content.title: Why do I need Royal Collagen Peptides to promote bone health?
content.content: About 70% of our bones are made of inorganic minerals and 10% of water. Collagen makes up the remaining 20% and forms the basic framework of the bone to which calcium “attaches.” Imagine calcium as the concrete bridge and collagen as the steel core. Calcium provides the mineral component of the structure’s strength. For this reason, Royal Collagen Peptides’ consumption is essential for helping maintain bone health. If collagen is missed in your body, the degradation of bone mass along with the stability of high-density bone is compromised. Royal Collagen Peptides help support bone health and improve bone stability and flexibility by stimulating the activity of the osteoblasts, the cell types responsible for the collagen biosynthesis (absorption) in the bone.

content.title: Why do I need Royal collagen peptides for promoting joint health?
content.content: Cartilage is a fundamental constituent of our joints. It acts as a shock absorber when two bones meet at the joint, allowing frictionless, smooth movement while protecting the bones and joints. Since cartilage is not connected to the bloodstream, it receives its nutrients via synovial fluid that acts like a lubricant film and supplies the sponge-like cartilage with nutrients. This works through movement and pressure. Exercise is essential for providing the cartilage with nutrients. Royal collagen peptides stimulate the activity of the chondrocytes. Chondrocytes are cell types responsible for the collagen biosynthesis in the cartilage. They produce and maintain cartilage matrix.

content.title: Do Royal Collagen Peptides trigger allergies?
content.content: Collagen peptides are considered non-allergic. Their structure is very similar to that of the body’s natural collagen. For that reason, collagen peptides are not regarded as a foreign substance that must be combated, even in a very sensitive immune system. This is why medical sponges made of collagen are used in surgical procedures. For example, a surgeon uses them to stop bleeding and leaves them in place to continue to regulate blood flow after the operation. The surgeon simply sutures the incision, and the sponges are absorbed and degraded in the body in a few weeks. Nevertheless, if you suffer from allergies, we recommend consulting your healthcare professional before taking this product.

content.title: Can a person with diabetes take Royal Collagen Peptides?
content.content: For people with diabetes who have to keep their blood glucose level under control, collagen peptides are ideal energy and protein sources. Royal Collagen Peptides support the functionality of collagenous structures in the skin, so they can also help improve healing time.

content.title: Can I take Royal Collagen Peptides while pregnant or breastfeeding?
content.content: We recommend talking with your healthcare professional first before taking our product because nutritional needs vary when pregnant or breastfeeding.

content.title: Do Royal Collagen Peptides taste like protein drinks?
content.content: Our Royal Collagen Peptides taste nothing like conventional protein powders and peptides. Because of their neutral taste and excellent dissolution properties, many customers mix theirs with breakfast cereal, yogurt, or cold drinks.

content.title: How many calories do Royal Collagen Peptides contain?
content.content: Like the other proteins, Royal Collagen Peptides have a caloric value of4 kilocalories per gram. Fat, for example, has 9 kilocalories per gram, and alcohol has no less than 7. If you take the recommended quantity of 2.5 grams of collagen peptides daily for your skin, that amounts to only 10 kilocalories.For muscle building and body toning, the recommended 15 grams totals up to 60kilocalories. Royal Collagen Peptides can increase and prolong the feeling of being full and counteract food cravings, which makes them ideal for weight management.

content.title: Can I consume Royal Collagen Peptides when I am working out?
content.content: Yes. Inadequate collagen levels in the body make connective tissue moreprone to injury, so consuming Royal Collagen Peptides can help protect muscles,ligaments, tendons, joints, and bones.

content.title: Can I mix Royal Collagen Peptides with hot drinks?
content.content: Our Royal Collagen Peptides Proprietary Blend contains pharmaceutical grade Vitamin C, which is very sensitive to heat. The increased temperature rapidly boosts its degradation. Vitamin C is vital for the absorption of iron and the biosynthesis of collagen in the human body. That’s why we recommend consuming Royal Collagen Peptides with cold liquid, cold juice, smoothies, yogurt, cold soups, or salads.

content.title: Where do you source your Collagen Peptides?
content.content: Our collagen peptides are bovine sourced exclusively from trustedEuropean suppliers and not from multiple untraceable animal sources fromthird-world countries. Our bovines are subjected to the strictest of veterinaryinspections before being released for human consumption, ensuring that anycontamination of the final product is avoided.

content.title: Why is natural Vitamin C added to Royal Collagen Peptides?
content.content: Royal Collagen Peptides are carefully blended with a potent and completely natural form of Vitamin C. Clinical research has proven that skin health is significantly improved when taking a collagen supplement combined with Vitamin C. However, choosing the right source of Vitamin C is crucial.Clinical studies have shown that taking Vitamin C and collagen peptide supplements ensures a healthy biosynthesis of collagen within the whole body.

content.title: Where do you source your Vitamin C?
content.content: The vast majority of Vitamin C (ascorbic acid) used in supplements on the market today is synthetically or artificially manufactured, often in China.Our experts opted to use a vastly superior, wholly natural, and clinically proven source known as the Red Orange Complex® from Sicily. The Red Orange Complex contains a standardized powder extract obtained from the juice of three pigmented (Moro, Tarocco, and Sanguinello) varieties ofSicilian blood oranges that are exclusively grown in a particular area nearMount Etna volcano in Sicily.

content.title: What do Sicilian Blood Oranges come from?
content.content: Sicilian Blood Oranges come from the greatest blood orange trees in the world, grow on the side of the Mount Etna volcano, where climate and soil are perfect for this kind of tree. No one else in the world has access to it. Sicilians call this orange “the ultimate healthy fruit.”

content.title: Why is Collagen Important?
content.content: It is well known that the human body consists mainly of water. Proteinsare the other major component. When referring to the heart, lungs, kidneys,liver, brain, skin, bones, and even most hormones and enzymes that areindispensable for metabolism, it is always the proteins that provide theirstructure and function. Collagen is the most abundant component in the humanbody, and therefore an essential component of human connective tissue. Thisextraordinary protein is also the central building block of the bones, joints,tendons, and many other tissues and structures. Collagen provides a structure for the body and its many organs and keepsthem “together” in the truest sense of the word. It is present nearlyeverywhere in the body, forming and connecting moving parts, like the bones,and in turn, the muscles, tendons, and ligaments with the bones.

content.title: How many types of collagen exists?
content.content: Currently, we know of 28 different types of collagen. The human bodymainly consists of collagen types I, II, and III. Type I accounts for about 90%of the body’s total collagen content, mainly in the connective tissue of theskin, bones, and tendons. Type II accounts for joint cartilage, and type IIIaccounts for skin and muscles.

content.title: What are collagen peptides?
content.content: The body keeps itself young by breaking down old tissue and building new tissue. As we age, this process slows down. When our body breaks down collagen, these long chains are disassembled, by enzymes, into small “snippets'' for removal. This sends a signal to the body to start rebuilding. A young and healthy body reacts to build the required quantity, but as we age, our metabolism becomes weary, and these signals are no longer enough for the body, which is becoming sluggish. When we consume collagen peptides as a dietary supplement, we ingest just these collagen snippets but in more significant amounts. Our bodies are rapidly digesting and absorbing collagen, mainly in the form of the smallest units, single amino acids, but also partially in intact form as collagen peptides (collagen snippets). These collagen snippets reach the bloodstream and distribute throughout the body. Collagen peptides stimulate our body’s collagen production. The whole connective tissue metabolism comes to life. Taking the skin as an example, it can be shown that other vital components of skin structure, such as elastin and proteoglycans, are also produced in significant quantities. The dermis, the second layer of skin, is completely overhauled. At the same time, the degradation of the skin is slowed. In total, more collagen is being built up than broken down, and it is precisely this effect that many users describe as amore attractive, firmer, radiant complexion. The balance also shifts in other tissue types such as cartilage or bone:increased formation, slower degradation. This also explains why dietary supplements cannot produce visible or tangible results instantly. Our body needs time to adapt to these processes. It is important to note one thing, collagen peptides not only affect the symptoms but also address the causes of the problems directly.

content.title: What are Specific Collagen Peptides?
content.content: We have come up with a method of cutting the snippets out of the long chain of amino acids “to size” in an exact way. Specific Collagen Peptides are optimized for different purposes and particular conditions.

content.title: What is the difference between collagen and collagen peptides?
content.content: Collagen molecules themselves are very large, so the body has difficulty using and absorbing them. Collagen peptides are obtained from collagen.Collagen peptides are collagen molecules cut smaller, allowing our body to make good use of them and their excellent bioavailability.

content.title: What does aging mean for metabolism?
content.content: When we are young, our metabolism runs at full speed, and our body cells are constantly renewing themselves. The nutrient uptake works flawlessly, and the body’s production of essential substances helps to ensure that it gets everything it needs. But as we grow older, many processes in the body change.Our entire metabolism slows down, and the untack and processing of nutrients declines. Certain tissues within the body are no longer reproduced at the required levels. Cartilage tissue wears out, bones become more porous, blood vessels calcify and stiffen, and the skin loses its ability to store moisture.These aging processes cannot be stopped. They can, however, be influenced by physical activity and a targeted diet with nutritional supplementation.

content.title: What does bioavailability mean?
content.content: The body can absorb collagen peptides efficiently because they are water-soluble and, unlike other proteins, have a straightforward peptide structure that is very easy for the body to work with. They are broken down with an enzymatic process called exogenous enzymatic hydrolysis and can be absorbed more quickly than natural collagen.

content.title: I am a vegetarian. Is there anything similar of plant origin?
content.content: There are indeed a multitude of plant-based proteins, for example, soy and hemp. However, they cannot replace collagen peptides as nutritional supplements. Our body is not made of plant origin. In purely biological terms, we are “animals,” and the collagen peptides of warm-blooded animals correspond to our body’s collagen building blocks molecular structure. This means that our body recognizes them as quasi naturally-produced proteins and can easily absorb and utilize them.

content.title: What does aging Mean?
content.content: When we are young, our metabolism runs at full speed and our body cells are constantly renewing themselves. The nutrient uptake works flawlessly, and the body’s own production of important substances also helps to ensure the body’s gets everything it needs. We are bursting with strengths and youthfulness. But as we grow older, many processes in the body change. Our entire metabolism slows down and the untack and processing of nutrients decline. Certain tissues within the body are no longer reproduced at the required levels. Cartilage tissue wears out, bones become more porous, blood vessels calcify and stiffen. The blood flow decreases, and as a result neither the tissue nor the brain is optimally provided for. The skin loses its ability to store moisture. These aging processes cannot be halted or reversed. They can, however, be influenced by physical activity and a targeted diet with nutritional supplementation.

content.title: Why is Collagen Important?
content.content: It is well known that the human body consists largely of water. Proteins are the other major component. When referring to the heart, lungs, kidneys, liver, brain, skin, bones, and even most hormones and enzymes that are indispensable for metabolism, it is always the proteins that provide their structure and function. Collagen is the most abundant component in the human body, and therefore the most important component of human connective tissue. This extraordinary protein is also the central building block of the bones, joints, tendons, and many other tissues and structures. Collagen provides a structure for the body and its many organs, and keeps them “together” in the truest sense of the word. It is present nearly everywhere in the body, forming and connecting moving parts, like the bones, and in turn, the muscles, tendons, and ligaments with the bones.

content.title: How many types of collagen exist?
content.content: Currently we know of 28 different types of collagen. The human body mainly consists of collagen types I, II and III. Type I accounts for about 90% of the body’s total collagen content, mainly in the connective tissue of the skin, bones, and tendons. Type II accounts for joint cartilage, and type III accounts for skin and muscles.

content.title: What are collagen peptides?
content.content: When we are young, our body is busy day and night performing renovation work. It keeps itself young by breaking down old tissue, while at the same time building new tissue to replace old. As we age, this process slows down, but it never ceases. When our body breaks down collagen, these long chains are disassembled, by enzymes, into small “snippets'' for removal. This sends a signal to the body: “Attention! Bits of degraded collagen are floating around here; we have to start rebuilding.” A young and healthy body reacts promptly to build the required quantity. As we age, our metabolism becomes weary and these signals are no longer enough for the body, which is becoming sluggish. When we consume collagen peptides as a dietary supplement, we ingest just these collagen snippets, but in larger amounts. Our bodies are rapidly digesting and absorbing collagen, mainly in the form of the smallest units, single amino acids, but also partially in intact form as collagen peptides (collagen snippets). These collagen snippets reach the bloodstream and distribute throughout the body. Now the cells in our body, which are responsible for connective tissue/collagen metabolism, notice that there is an imbalance. It is like an alarm, “Attention! There are lots of collagen particles swimming about here, now we really have to get work and make even more collagen!” As the collagen supplements provide the amino acids, building blocks for collagen synthesis at the same time, they support the body twofold. In this way, collagen peptides stimulate our body’s own collagen production. The whole connective tissue metabolism comes to life. Taking the skin as an example, it can be shown that other important components of skin structure, such as elastin and proteoglycans, are also produced in great quantities. The dermis, the second layer of skin, is, so to speak, completely overhauled. At the same time the degradation of the skin is slowed. In total, more collagen is being built up than broken down, and it is exactly this effect that many users, mostly women, describe as a more attractive, firmer, radiant complexion. The balance also shifts in other tissue types such as cartilage or bone: increased formation, slower degradation. This also explains why dietary supplements cannot produce visible or tangible results instantly disappear. Our body needs time to adapt to these processes. It is important to note one thing, collagen peptides do not only affect the symptoms, but also address the causes of the problems directly.

content.title: Where do you source natural Astaxanthin from?
content.content:
Astaxanthin is a naturally occurring pigment that gives the reddish pink color to marine organisms such as crabs, shrimp, and salmon. It is often called the “King of Carotenoids” because of its powerful antioxidant potency. Astaxanthin also possesses a unique molecular structure that spans the cell membrane’s hydrophilic and hydrophobic layers, attracting and quenching free radicals. Our natural Astaxanthin is derived from a wholly natural source, the microalgae Haematococcus pluvialis, and contains the same form of astaxanthin found in wild salmon. Our natural astaxanthin is produced in Japan and Sweden.

Astaxanthin is made by the algae Haematoccous pluvialis in response to stresses that produce free radicals. Astaxanthin is called a “secondary carotenoid” because algae make it using beta-carotene as one of the starting materials for making astaxanthin. Astaxanthin is fat-loving organic hydrocarbon with the chemical formula C40H52O4. It has a central chain of carbons with alternating single and double bonds (also known as conjugated double bonds), which is a special structure that allows astaxanthin to neutralize free radicals. The oxygen-containing rings at each end of the astaxanthin molecule fit on the edges of cell membranes, giving astaxanthin the unique ability to span the whole membrane for full protection from free radical damage.

content.title: What is Inflammation?
content.content: Inflammation is a buzzword that really means stress. Bruising and swelling, for example, are signs that inflammation is tending to an injury. But when inflammation doesn’t turn off, this long-term stress can lead to serious health problems.

content.title: How does the immune system work?
content.content:
The immune system is made up of two armies of cells; innate and acquired. Innate immune cells are the body's first line of defense. They quickly respond to foreign cells to fight infection, battle a virus or defend the body against bacteria. Our acquired immunity—also called adaptive immunity—uses T-cells and B-cells when invading organisms slip through that first line. These cells take longer to develop because their behaviors evolve from learned experiences, but they tend to live longer than innate cells. Adaptive immune cells remember foreign invaders after their first encounter and fight them off the next time they enter the body. This is the fundamental premise for how vaccines work—using a small, harmless amount of protein from a disease to allow the immune system to recognize that protein if the pathogen were to invade the body.

B-cells and T-cells are also called lymphocytes. “There are primary and secondary lymphoid organs involved in the complex development of lymphocytes,” says Pamela Crilley, DO, Chair of the Department of Medical Oncology at Cancer Treatment Centers of America (CTCA). “The primary lymphoid tissues in the initial generation of B- and T-lymphocytes are the bone marrow and the thymus.”

B-cells fight bacteria and viruses by making Y-shaped proteins called antibodies, which are specific to each pathogen and are able to lock onto the surface of an invading cell and mark it for destruction by other immune cells.

content.title: What do T-cells do?
content.content:
There are two main types of T-cells; helper T-cells and killer T-cells. Helper T-cells stimulate B-cells to make antibodies and help killer cells develop. Killer T-cells directly kill cells that have already been infected by a foreign invader. T-cells also use cytokines as messenger molecules to send chemical instructions to the rest of the immune system to ramp up its response.

While both are critical to the body's defense against disease and infection, T-cells and B-cells play very different roles.

content.title: Why is it important to boost your immune system, and how can I protect my immune system?
content.content:
Our body’s ability to fight infection and disease depends on our immune systems. The immune system is comprised of cells, tissues, and organs that work together to protect your body from illness and infection.

Since the immune system is not just a single entity, there isn’t a single food that you can eat or add to your diet to support it. The best way to keep your immune system running smoothly is to follow healthy living strategies that include.

Good Nutrition

Good nutrition is vital to supporting a healthy immune system. Follow a plant-based, heart-healthy menu that incorporates a variety of vegetables and fruits, whole grains, lean protein, and healthy fats. Eat small, frequent meals throughout the day to stay energized and ensure your body is getting enough calories, proteins, and nutrients.

Phytochemicals

Fruits, vegetables, and other plants contain a naturally occurring compound known as phytochemicals (or phytonutrients). Phytochemicals refer to a variety of compounds that give fruits and vegetables their color and flavor. Studies show that phytochemicals support the:

Immune system

Creation of healthy cells

Death of damaged cells. Phytochemicals also act as antioxidants to protect the body from damage.

Dietary Supplements

Dietary supplements help you get adequate amounts of essential nutrients if you don’t eat a nutritious variety of foods or if these nutrients cannot be taken from the food itself. However, make sure to always take dietary supplements that follow the highest standard quality control process. The FDA has established good manufacturing practices (GMPs) that companies must follow to help ensure the identity, purity, strength, and composition of their dietary supplements. These GMPs can prevent adding the wrong ingredient (or too much or too little of the correct ingredient) and reduce the chance of contamination or improper packaging and labeling of a product. The FDA periodically inspects facilities that manufacture supplements.

Lifestyle

Change your lifestyle to help support your health and immunity.

Get Enough Sleep

Sleep is an essential aspect of health. Our bodies need sleep to recharge and heal. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) recommends that adults get seven hours or more of sleep every night.

Minimize Stress

Stress can also take a toll on the immune system. In many ways, mental health can also affect your physical health. Try to reduce stress by taking time to do things you enjoy, such as spending time with family, spending time outdoors, or reading. If your feelings of anxiety or depression make it difficult for you to complete daily tasks, talk to your healthcare professional.

Exercise Regularly

Leading an active lifestyle can also support your immune system by promoting good circulation, allowing the cells and substances of the immune system to move through the body freely and do their job efficiently. Regular exercise promotes good cardiovascular (heart) health, too. The American Institute for Cancer Research (AICR) recommends getting at least 150 minutes of moderate activity or 75 minutes of vigorous physical activity a week. Physical activity includes walking, jogging, swimming, biking, playing sports, etc. Include strength training and stretching along with aerobic exercise to build muscle and increase flexibility.

Enjoy Life

Enjoy family, entertaining old friends, and making new ones; turn the simplest occasion into a social gathering for the entire neighborhood.

content.title: What is Blue Light?
content.content:
High energy blue light can damage our eyes. It is a component of visible light that we are exposed to it without even realizing it. Blue Light is not easily ﬁltered by our eyes, and over exposure can negatively impact vision.

Nearly every source of light—whether natural or artiﬁcial—emits harmful blue light. Over the last few years, the increasing use of technology anddigital devices means people are subjecting themselves to higher levels of BlueLight and risking harm to their eyes.

content.title: Who is affected by Blue Light?
content.content: Everyone who is exposed to digital devices. 60% of Americans use digital devices more than 5 hours daily; 75% of Americans use digital devices in the hour before going to sleep; 70% of Americans use 2 or more digital devices at the same time; 75% of those people report experiencing symptoms of ComputerVision Syndrome. Additionally, 33% of children use devices more than 3 hours daily; 87% of millennials use 2 or more devices simultaneously; 37% of millennials use devices more than 9 hours daily.

content.title: Does Blue Light exposure have short-term effects?
content.content: Yes, it does have short-term effects such as headaches, eye strain, blurred vision, eye fatigue, and dry eye.

content.title: Does Blue Light exposure have long-term effects?
content.content: Yes, it does have long-term effects such as retinal damage, reduced visual performance, poor glare recovery, and age-related eye conditions.

content.title: What is Computer Vision Syndrome?
content.content: In today’s world, every human being is taking advantage of technology. Technology is everywhere. We are glued to multiple digital devices; screens, phones, tablets, computers, and television. Studies have shown that over a third of adults spend more than half their day using technology, while others have admitted that their technology usage consumes 10–12 hours of their time per day. Adults aren’t the only ones being affected, as kids are becoming more involved with devices and other forms of technology at home and in the classroom. 50-90% of digital device users suffer Computer Vision Syndrome (CVS) or Digital Eye Strain symptoms.

content.title: What are common symptoms of Computer Vision Syndrome (CVS) or digital eye strain?
content.content:
- 33% report experiencing eye strain

- 23% report experiencing dry eyes

- 22% report experiencing blurred vision

content.title: Why is this happening to your eyes?
content.content: The eyes are naturally at rest with a view distance of 20 feet away, but by using a phone, tablet, or computer, they are generally 18-24 inches away. This causes a prolonged contraction of ciliary muscles, increasing ROS/free radicals and stressing the eyes. Ciliary muscles spasm to adjust to close proximity viewing—the eyes fatigue, resulting in blurred vision and headaches.

content.title: What is the role of the ciliary muscle in the eye?
content.content: Ciliary muscles adjust lens thickness to change the eye’s focal length. Ciliary muscle provides near point of focus, depth perception, positive accommodation speed, and accommodation amplitude.

content.title: What is an example of ciliary muscle function?
content.content: Ciliary muscles can contract, rounding the lens and allow you to focuson near objects. Additionally, ciliary muscles can relax, flattening the lensand enable you to focus on distant objects.

content.title: What is accommodation of the eye?
content.content: Accommodation is defined as the ability of the eye to change its focusfrom distant to near objects (and vice versa). A human eye can change focus from distance infinity to 7cm in 350 milliseconds. This dramatic change in focal power occurs as a consequence of reduction in the zonular tension induced by the ciliary muscle. Put simply, the circular ciliary muscles inside the eyes contract to focus on near subjects and relax to focus on distant subjects. During a long computer session, the eyes exert substantial energy to focus on the computer screen; therefore, vision can be temporarily blurred after a long computer session.

content.title: Why should I care about my Mitochondrial health?
content.content: We should care because healthier mitochondria result in better nourishment for the organelle that fuels all cell activity in the body. Also,an organism’s longevity is directly correlated to the amount of free radical damage created within the mitochondria. Without your mitochondria producing enough Adenosine Tri-Phosphate (ATP), every activity in your body would cease. ATP is a high-energy molecule that stores the energy we need to do just about everything we do. Our mitochondria produce the energy of life. For this reason, we need to secure more antioxidant protection from our diet to supplement the defenses our body makes.
